annotation.TEXT: As an important note: I'll try my best not to include annotations whenever any dialogue boxes are on screen, but I will be pushing the button to speed the text up (and then linger on it enough so that it can be read). The reason I'm doing this is because the text in this game is incredibly slow (and as far as I know, there's no option to make it faster).

It feels like it's been a long time since I've tackled an officially licensed Mega Man game. Time to fix that with something that very few people were probably expecting. If you're at all familiar with the Battle Network series but never heard of this game before, chances are this is going to be pretty confusing at first glance.
Also, YouTube kind of destroyed the quality of the jacking in animation. I'll look into fixing it for future segments, though there's no guarantee it will work out.

This section is kind of a pain to traverse. It's not required to, but you can get a few helpful items if you pull it off right. These include a Memory Up (this increases what's basically your MP, represented by the green bar to the right of your life), along with a Power-Up, which is used to increase one of three stats of your buster (Attack, Rapid, and Charge).

And do you know what the sad thing is? There's a number of easy ways to deal with this guy, but the solutions themselves aren't well communicated in the slightest. For example: Sliding seems like the correct way to dodge the Fire-Arm attack, right? Well...that's partially true. Do you know what the actual, intended way for you to avoid this is? You need to slide through his legs. No, I'm not kidding. In fact, you can do this with almost every single boss - and yet, I don't think it's ever once hinted at that you can.

Mystery Datas are one of your main sources of various items in this game. You can generally tell what will be in the data based on its color: Green is your standard data that contains something random from a fixed pool of items (usually a small amount of zenny or a battle chip). Blue data usually contains stat upgrades, sub-chips, or occasionally a strong battle chip. Purple data tends to contain similar upgrades to blue data, but the data itself is locked. You won't be able to get whatever is inside it without forking over some money for an Unlocker sub-chip first.

Putting a point into your Charge stat will let you charge your buster...but it starts off incredibly slow and weak. While the buster itself can be really good once you power it up enough, it's still going to take a while to make it worth using.

Fun fact: Spikes in this game aren't really an instant kill. Sure, this early on they're pretty lethal, but once you get more HP, you'll soon realize that they just do a ton of damage instead of outright killing you.

That thing that looks like a blue battle chip is called a Back Up. Essentially, it's an extra life. Much like whenever I play the classic series, you're probably not going to see me go out of my way for them.
There are several other aspects to go over as well, such as the fact that enemies can drop battle chips, along with certain stats/items, though I'll point them out as they become relevant.

Since the buster starts off really weak, your best method for attacking comes from battle chips. When you first jack in, you'll be given 5 random chips from your folder (the folder itself can hold up to 30 battle chips). While the battle chips themselves have various effects, you generally don't have to worry too much about running out of them. Almost every chip can be used multiple times, and the use amount can be increased if you pick up or buy a copy of that chip. With that being said, each chip does have a maximum use count it will eventually hit (for example, you can only have 20 V-Gun chips in total).

There are a few more general things to note on with these boss fights (which I'll be saving for the start of the next segment), but if you want an even easier way to beat FireMan.EXE, I encourage you to stick around to the end of the video.

Oh, and we also have cyber-bars in this game. These work almost the same way as the ones in X5 and X6: You hold up, and you latch onto them. Since there's no dash ability in this game though (well, aside from the Dash chip), there's no way to move faster while on them.

As for yellow data, those contain key items to advance the plot (and in one case, provides something that gets you a different ending). On another important note: green data respawns every time you jack into the net, but blue and purple data can only be collected once.

You start the game with two Bubbler chips, but if you get a bit of money and jack out, nothing is stopping you from buying two more from Higsby. You also start the game with enough MB to select Bubbler as your default chip without having to find Reg-Up's. Do this, and you can literally kill FireMan.EXE in 4 hits when you first encounter him.

Wasting the Repair chip here to eliminate it from the possible chip selection. The game tries to encourage its use on things like crumbling platforms, but there's really no need for it (although you can use it in certain spots to get secret codes, but even then, the codes themselves are useless to you unless you plan on playing BN3).

Time to take the news' advice and select a default chip: In this case, we'll go with Bubbler, the only Aqua-based chip we have right now. This in turn leads me to the other easy way of beating FireMan.EXE, along with the elemental weakness system. Every element is weak to something (Fire > Wood > Elec > Aqua > Back to Fire, and so on), and when you hit something with its elemental weakness, you'll deal double damage.

Mega Man Battle Network Transmission is essentially a game that combines the overall characters/setting/themes from the BN series with a good chunk of the gameplay from the classic series. Although I could just leave the main description at that, there's actually a bit more to this game (which in turn, will soon lead into the reasons why many people don't like it).

Time to go over the basics of how this game works (hence why I skipped through a good portion of the tutorial dialogue). Starting off, MegaMan.EXE has MM3-styled abilities. You can't charge your buster (yet), but you can slide.

We're now approaching the reason that I believe so many people never bothered with this game...and to be honest, I can't blame them. In my opinion, FireMan.EXE is one of the cruelest opening bosses in any video game ever. Let me put it to you like this: His attacks deal such massive damage that - even if you equipped the Heat Armor and got the HP Memory earlier - he can kill you in basically 2 or 3 hits. That's not even going into his attacks, which include two fire auras if you get close to him (one of which can knock off over half your health), and a fire-wave that covers the entire horizontal space in front of him.

A lot of the blue mystery datas in this place aren't accessible just yet. They'll eventually open up once FireMan.EXE is defeated. Even then however, you'll still need some help from the Dash chip to obtain one of them.
One wallpaper later...

Also, going back through here since the game forces you into that teleporter when you first approach it. This is mostly just to get a mystery data hiding behind the portal itself (something that this game will pull several more times).

This is a bit of a nitpick on my part, but something I've always had an issue with (even in the original BN series) is that MegaMan.EXE's overworld appearance never changes when you equip armor to him (or even when he gets a style change, for that matter). Hell, a simple palette swap to make him red when he puts on the Heat Armor would have been fine by me - just so long as it gets some kind of acknowledgement.
